item.title: Creating and Recreating Virtual Community on Douglass Day
item.author: Justin Smith, Courtney Murray, Jim Casey
item.description: Save the Date for Douglass Day 2022! Help us find the names of Black women in the Colored Conventions. Where did they go? Registration is now open. Sign up for updates & more! https://t.co/nbxI9l1lGT pic.twitter.com/5bz5fRQVLR — Douglass Day (@DouglassDayorg) October 8, 2021 Save the Date for Douglass Day 2022! Help us find the names of Black women in the Colored Conventions. Where did they go? Registration is now open.

item.title: Data's Destinations: Three Case Studies in Crowdsourced Transcription Data Management and Dissemination
item.author: Victoria Anne Van Hyning, Mason A. Jones
item.description: Online crowdsourcing—a series of methods for engaging volunteers with STEM, humanities, and cultural heritage research—has rapidly matured between 2000 and 2021.

item.title: Serendipity in the Cairo Geniza
item.author: Matthew Dudley, Steffy Reader
item.description: Matthew Dudley is a PhD candidate at Yale University where he is completing a dissertation on the early modern Cairo Geniza of the sixteenth through nineteenth centuries. Steffy Reader, a retired psychotherapist, has contributed to the Scribes of the Cairo Geniza and a number of other Zooniverse projects since 2018. In the clip below, they meet for the first time during the conference Crowdsourcing and the Humanities and discover that they had already been collaborating anonymously via the Scribes of the Cairo Geniza site.

item.title: “Strangers in the Landscape”: On Research Development and Making Things for Making
item.author: Samantha Blickhan, Will Granger, Shaun A. Noordin, Becky Rother
item.description: This piece is about making in support of making. It is about projects born from myriad goals that gather new objectives along their lifecycle, through evaluation and iteration.

item.title: Data Beyond Vision
item.author: Rebecca Sutton Koeser, Gissoo Doroudian, Nick Budak, Xinyi Li
item.description: How do we represent tangible objects in a visual medium? We use words, pictures, and diagrams. We describe, share, show, and fail.

item.title: Print a Model of the Shakespeare and Company Lending Library Membership
item.author: Rebecca Sutton Koeser
item.description: Print a model of Shakespeare and Company lending library membership by date, as described in “Data Beyond Vision”

item.title: Stack Shakespeare and Company Membership Activities
item.author: Xinyi Li, Rebecca Sutton Koeser
item.description: Create your own kirigami model of the Shakespeare and Company lending library membership activities, as described in “Data Beyond Vision”

item.title: Their Data, Ourselves: Illness as Information
item.author: Rebecca Munson
item.description: When I was growing up I liked to read about dying children. I’m not talking about the Victorian orphan kind of dying, not the dying of storybooks, but children who were terminally ill.

item.title: Weave Derrida's References
item.author: Gissoo Doroudian
item.description: Create your own data weaving of Derrida’s references in chapter 1 of de la Grammatologie, as described in “Data Beyond Vision”

item.title: About
item.description: <dl> <dt>startword, <abbr title="noun">n.</abbr></dt> <dd>(computer science) A string of letters that identifies the beginning of a valid sequence in a specified language.</dd> <dd>(literature) The first appearance of a genre in print.</dd> </dl>

item.title: Weaving as Interface
item.author: Rebecca Sutton Koeser, Gissoo Doroudian
item.description: As a way of turning this data weaving into an interface, we offer an experiment with an annotated deep-zoom image of the weaving linked to information about the references it represents.
